forecast.review: Both forecasters correctly emphasize the huge gap (.112) and the short runway to June 15. I found Forecaster 3’s framing of what it would take for another team to undercut the Rockies helpful, though their specific example slightly understates how extreme the collapse would need to be: using a plausible White Sox base of ~14-35 (.286) with ~27 games to June 15, for Colorado finishing around .219 (e.g., 8 more wins), the Sox would need roughly 2-25 (not 3-24) to fall below that mark. That correction actually strengthens the Yes case. Forecaster 2’s 95% is directionally consistent given the fundamentals and schedule; the variance allowance is the main reason not to go even higher. Neither added materially new data beyond what I’d considered, but the threshold-style check (even with the minor math slip) is a useful cross-check that supports nudging the probability up.
forecast.rationale: The Rockies’ current position (8-38, .174) with the next-worst around .286, plus league-worst underlying indicators and a tough schedule, makes it very hard for anyone to pass them by June 15. Over ~25–27 games, even if Colorado improves meaningfully (say .300 ball), they’d still sit near .22 overall; for another team at ~.286 after ~45–49 games to drop below that in such a short span requires an extremely severe collapse (on the order of ≤2–3 wins in ~27 games) or, alternatively, for Colorado to play around .450–.500 while a rival plays ≤.250. Both joint scenarios are low probability. Managerial change and returning players may modestly lift Colorado, but not enough to erase the gap quickly. The resolution nuance (“checked on or after June 15”) introduces only minor additional uncertainty. Given these checks—and correcting Forecaster 3’s threshold math which, if anything, makes the No path even less likely—I’m moving my estimate up slightly from 90% to 94%.
